Translated by Zhi Qian, UpÄsaka of the State of Yuezhi in the Wu Dynasty
Thus have I heard: Once, the Buddha was at Mount Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a in the country of RÄjagá¹›ha, together with five hundred bhiká¹£us.
At that time, the king of the country of RÄjagá¹›ha was named Prasenajit. From a young age, as the crown prince, he always sought five vows:
First, May I become king at a young age;
Second, May there be a Buddha in my country;
Third, May I always come and go to where the Buddha is;
Fourth, May I always listen to the Buddha's sutras;
Fifth, May my mind quickly awaken upon hearing the sutras, and attain the path of srota-Äpanna.
These five vows, King Prasenajit all attained them.
At that time, to the north of the country of RÄjagá¹›ha, there was another country named DevakÅ«á¹­a IrÄ.

The king of that country was named Pukkasa, who was extremely noble and extraordinary. In his past life, he had already met the Buddha, received the Buddha's teachings, and studied the Sutra on the Six Aspects of the Body.
What are the six aspects?
First, the body contains earth; second, the body contains water; third, the body contains fire; fourth, the body contains wind; fifth, the body contains space; sixth, the body contains mind.
The body generally has these six aspects.

King Bimbisara and King Pukkasa had never met each other since birth, but they had a deep affection for each other like brothers. They always wrote letters back and forth, exchanging gifts without interruption.
King Bimbisara always thought:
I wish I could obtain an extremely rare and wonderful item to give to King Pukkasa.
King Pukkasa also always thought:
I wish I could obtain an extremely rare and wonderful item to give to King Bimbisara.
In the kingdom of King Pukkasa, a lotus flower suddenly appeared, with a thousand petals, all golden in color.
He sent a messenger to give it as a gift to King Bimbisara.
King Bimbisara saw the flower and was overjoyed, saying:
King Pukkasa has given me a gift that is very extraordinary.
King Bimbisara wrote a letter to King Pukkasa, saying:
In our country, there are many precious things such as gold and silver, but I do not consider them precious.
Now, in our country, a human flower has appeared, called the Buddha, with a body of purple-gold color and thirty-two marks.
When King Pukkasa read the letter and heard the word Buddha, he was overjoyed and his body hair stood on end - because he had seen the Buddha in a past life, his hair stood on end.
King Pukkasa wrote a letter to King Bimbisara:
I wish to hear in detail the teachings and admonitions practiced by the divine Buddha, which I will uphold and practice.
Please inform me of your thoughts in detail.
After several days, King Pukkasa thought to himself:
Human life cannot be known, it is between breaths.
I cannot wait for the reply from Pukkasa, it is better to go see the Buddha myself.
King Pukkasa was the ruler of ninety-nine small countries, and the kings of the small countries came to pay their respects.
Pukkasa ordered the kings of the small countries, his ministers, and officials, and all the troops, to be fully equipped and set out to the Buddha's place in Rajagriha.
On the way, they encountered King Pukkasa's letter, which said:
The Buddha teaches people to abandon their families, give up their wives and children, cut off desires, shave their beards and hair, wear Dharma robes, and become monks.
Why is this?
Because people are foolish, they do what they should not do and become deluded.
From delusion comes action;
from action comes consciousness;
from consciousness comes name and form;
from name and form come the six sense bases.
What are the six sense bases?
First, eyes; second, ears; third, nose; fourth, mouth; fifth, body; sixth, mind.
These are the six.
These six things all face outward:
Eyes face colors;
Ears face sounds;
Nose faces smells;
Mouth faces tastes;
Body faces smoothness;
Mind faces desires.
These are the six directions.
From the six directions, they combine;ğŸ”½From combining, there is pain and pleasure;
From pain and pleasure, there is craving;ğŸ”½From craving, there is grasping;
From grasping, there is becoming;
From becoming, there is birth;
From birth, there is old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and unhappiness. Thus, the great mass of suffering arises in accordance with one's habits.
Generally, this combination of toil and suffering is called a person.
The wise one removes ignorance by himself;
When ignorance is exhausted, all evils are eliminated;
When evils are eliminated, then actions are exhausted;
When actions are exhausted, consciousness is exhausted;
When consciousness is exhausted, name-and-form is exhausted;
Name and form cease, the six sense bases cease;
The six sense bases cease, contact ceases;ğŸ”½Contact ceases, feeling ceases;ğŸ”½Feeling ceases, craving ceases;
Craving ceases, clinging ceases;
Clinging ceases, existence ceases;
Existence ceases, birth ceases;
Birth ceases, old age and death cease;
When old age and death cease, sorrow, lamentation, pain, unhappiness, and distress cease. Thus is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering.
Not arising is the attainment of nirvana, the unconditioned.
King Pukkasati finished reading and thought to himself.
In the still of the night, when everyone was asleep, he quietly got up and left, entering a cemetery, where he shaved his head and put on Dharma robes, becoming a monk.
Not having a begging bowl, he took an old human skull from the cemetery, cleaned it thoroughly, and used it as his begging bowl.
Holding this skull bowl, he wandered and arrived at the kingdom of King BimbisÄra of RÄjagá¹›ha.
He stopped outside the city, looked up at the sun, and thought:
It is too late to go to the Buddha today, I will go tomorrow.
King Prasenajit previously reported to the potter:
I wish to stay for one night.
The potter said:
Very good!
My house is fortunately spacious, there is a place to stay.
King Prasenajit took a small grass mat outside, entered, spread out the seat in a screened place, sat on it, and contemplated the five internal organs by himself.
The Buddha used his heavenly eye to see from Vulture Peak that King Prasenajit was coming and stopped outside the city of RÄjagá¹›ha at the potter's house.
The Buddha thought that King Prasenajit's life would end tomorrow and he would not be able to see each other again.
The Buddha then flew and arrived outside the door of the potter's house.
The Buddha said to the potter:
I wish to stay for one night.
The potter replied:
My house is fortunately large, so it can accommodate you.
Recently, a monk came to stay overnight. I will inform him and if he is comfortable with it, you can stay.
The Buddha then went to King Pukkasati and said:
I have entrusted myself to the host for one night, and he said he would inform you.
Would you allow me to stay for one night?
Pukkasati said:
I just have a small grass mat, just enough to sit on.
This house is fortunately spacious, you can stay wherever you want.
The Buddha then took the small grass mat to the left and right, and sat in one place.
The Buddha sat upright for three nights, and Pukkasati also sat upright.
The Buddha thought to himself:
This Pukkasati sits upright, silent, unmoving, and unshakable.
The Buddha wanted to test him, so he asked why he became a monk,ğŸ”½what scriptures and precepts he received,
and what scriptures he liked.
The Buddha arrived in front of Pukkusa and asked:
Whose teachings does your teacher accept?
For what reasons did you become a monk?
Pukkusa replied:
I heard that there is a Buddha, surnamed Gautama, whose father is named Shuddhodana, the king of the Shakya clan.
His son shaved his head and beard, became a monk, and attained Buddhahood.
I serve him as my teacher.
I became a monk because of the Buddha.
The sutras spoken by the Buddha have entered my heart, and I am very pleased with them.
The Buddha asked:
Have you ever seen the Buddha?
Pukkusa said:
No, I have not seen him.
Even if you saw him, would you be able to recognize him as the Buddha?
Pukkusa said:
If I saw him, I would not be able to recognize him.
The Buddha thought:
This wise one became a monk because of me.
I will continue to explain to him the sutra of knowing past lives, and then he will understand quickly.
The Buddha said to Pukkasa:
I will expound the sutra for you. The beginning is good, the middle is good, and the end is good.
I will explain the six aspects of the body for you. Listen well!
Pukkasa said:
Very good!
The Buddha said:
These six things can come together to form a human body.
A human body has six things that give rise to awareness.
Human intentions are moved by eighteen things.
There are four things that monks should practice;
having practiced them, the mind will no longer turn;
if the mind no longer turns, one will attain the Way;

having attained the Way, one will not be reborn, will not age, will not get sick, will not die in this world, will not die in the next world, will not grieve, will not worry, will not be angry, will not think, and will not love.
This is the way to transcend the world.
Please explain the six things that are collectively called the person.
Listen carefully!
First, earth, second, water, third, fire, fourth, wind, fifth, space, sixth, mind.
What is earth?
Earth has two categories:
The body's earth and external earth.
What is the body's earth?
It refers to hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, spleen, kidneys, liver, lungs, intestines, and stomach.
All the hard things in the body are earth.
The body's earth and external earth are combined into earth. The body's earth and external earth are not one's earth. One should have no further greed or attachment to learning.
One should carefully contemplate and thus understand oneself.
What is water?
Water has two categories:
The body's water and external water.
What is the body's water?
Namely, tears, mucus, saliva, pus, blood, sweat, fat, marrow, brain, and urine:
All the soft things in the body are water.

The water in the body and external water are combined as water. The water in the body and external water are not my water. There is nothing to be greedy for. One should contemplate carefully and understand by oneself.
What is fire?
There are two kinds of fire:
Body fire and external fire.
What is body fire?
It refers to the warmth in the body and the digestion in the stomach:
All the heat in the body is fire.
Body fire and external fire are combined as fire. Body fire and external fire are not my fire. There is nothing to be greedy for. One should contemplate carefully and understand by oneself.
What is wind?
There are two kinds of wind:
Body wind and external wind.
What is body wind?
Namely, the upper wind, the lower wind, the wind between the bones, the wind in the abdomen, the wind in the four limbs, and the wind of breathing.
All the arising in the body is wind.
The body wind and the external wind are combined as wind, the body wind and the external wind are not my wind, just without further greed and desire to learn.
One should contemplate carefully and understand by oneself.
What is emptiness?
Emptiness has two aspects:
The emptiness of the body and the emptiness of the external.
What is meant by the emptiness of the body?
It refers to the emptiness of the eyes, ears, nose, mouth, throat, abdomen, stomach, and the passage of food in and out.
This is the emptiness of the body.

The emptiness of the body and the emptiness of the external are combined as emptiness, the emptiness of the body and the external emptiness are not my emptiness, just without further greed and desire to learn.
One should contemplate carefully and understand by oneself.
The wise who study the Way can distinguish and know the five parts of the body by themselves, and the remaining part is the mind.
The mind is pure and free from desires, thinking to oneself:
'I am as pure as this.'

If one wishes to ascend to the twenty-fifth heaven of empty wisdom, fearing that one will not be able to escape even after living for thousands of eons in the twenty-five heavens,ğŸ”½if one further wishes to ascend to the twenty-sixth heaven of consciousness wisdom, with a lifespan twice that of the twenty-fifth heaven, fearing that one will still not be able to escape,
if one further wishes to ascend to the twenty-seventh heaven of thoughtless wisdom, with a lifespan twice that of the twenty-sixth heaven, fearing that one will still not be able to escape,
if one further wishes to ascend to the twenty-eighth heaven of no-thought, with a lifespan of 840 million eons, fearing that one will still not be able to escape.
The mind then becomes weary of suffering, and after a long life, one is unable to escape, so one attains the path of nirvana.
What are the six things that combine?

It refers to the eyes combining with form, the ears combining with sound, the nose combining with smell, the tongue combining with taste, the body combining with touch, and the mind combining with cognition.
These are the six unions.
What are the eighteen transformations of the mind?
The eyes transform for good colors, for bad colors, and for neutral colors;
The ears transform for good sounds, for sad sounds, and for bad sounds;
The nose transforms for good smells, for bad smells, and for foul smells;
The tongue transforms for delicious flavors, for bad flavors, and for bland flavors;
The body transforms for smoothness, for roughness, and for cold and warmth;
The mind transforms for good things, for bad things, and for worldly things.
These are the eighteen transformations of the mind.
What are the four things that firmly control people?
First, sincerity; second, equanimity; third, wisdom; fourth, eliminating all evils.
These are the four firm intentions.
What the eyes crave and obtain brings happiness;
Happiness leaves people, and they realize it is past.
From suffering, leading to suffering, one is able to know it as suffering;
Having left suffering, one knows for oneself the liberation from suffering.
When a person practices suffering, it is difficult to attain happiness, one should contemplate and cut off all evil things.
Because of attaining neither suffering nor happiness, one knows for oneself the distancing from all suffering.
It is like two pieces of wood rubbing together to produce fire, because of separating the two pieces of wood, placing them on different sides, the fire also goes out, and the wood becomes cold.
Affection and love combine to obtain suffering, abandoning affection and love, one knows for oneself the liberation.
It is like a goldsmith obtaining good gold, freely wanting to make what marvelous things - arm rings, earrings, jade steps, flower radiance and a hundred kinds - all he is able to make.

The practitioner should hold the mind like this, the goldsmith is free to want to be born, not allowing the desire to be born in the twenty-five heavens, the twenty-sixth heaven, the twenty-seventh heaven, the twenty-eighth heaven.
However, if one carefully examines all of this, although it may last for a long time, it will eventually perish. All will pass away, and there is nothing permanent.
Knowing that it will pass away again, the mind no longer turns towards it, no longer thinks of it, no longer contemplates it, and no longer desires it. This is called the unconditioned.
The wise person thinks to themselves, Only this is lofty;
Only when a person is far removed from evil can they be considered wise.
The eyes see that all things will pass away, and there is nothing permanent. The unconditioned neither goes away nor comes back.
The practitioner who knows this will then have faith in the unconditioned path, which is the most sincere.
Before attaining the Way, one delights in and loves the body and mind that are born;

After attaining the Way, one abandons them all. A person abandons their cherished affections, which is called the unconditioned.ğŸ”½Because the mind is attached to lust, one cannot attain liberation;ğŸ”½Because the mind is attached to anger, one cannot attain liberation;
Because the mind is attached to delusion, one cannot attain liberation.

The practitioner who knows this, then abandons the mind of lust, abandons the mind of anger, abandons the mind of delusion, uproots the root of affection, severs its branches and leaves, cuts off its roots and stems, and it will not grow again.
This is called the unconditioned.
Thinking to oneself, having a self moves the mind, not having a self also moves the mind, thinking one is upright moves the mind, thinking one is not upright also moves the mind.
If a person preemptively thinks like this, this is a disease, this is serious, this is painful, this is not liberation.
Therefore, one does not wish to think too much.
This is called the essence of all suffering.
Pukkusa did not know that this was the Buddha, but having attained the third stage of arhatship, he was able to recognize him as the Buddha.
He immediately got up, touched his head to the Buddha's feet and said:
I was truly foolish and presumptuous, and lost my propriety and respect.
The Buddha then manifested his radiance and majestic spiritual power.
Pukkusa then repented and said:
I am a foolish person.
The Buddha said:
If you can repent, it is good, and it will remove your faults.
Pukkasa said:
I wish to become a monk.
The Buddha asked:
If you become a monk, do you have the robes and alms bowl?
Pukkasa said:
I do not have them.
The Buddha said:
Without the robes and alms bowl of a monk, one cannot become a monk.
Pukkasa said:
Yes.
I will go and prepare them.
The Buddha said:
Very good!
Pukkasa rose, bowed to the Buddha, and circumambulated him three times.
The next day, Pukkasa entered the city.
Not far into the city, a young cow charged and gored Pukkasa with its horns.
The monks heard about it and said to the Buddha:
Did the Buddha allow him to speak the sutra at the potter's house yesterday?
The monk's words and conduct were complete, and he wore the robes and carried the alms bowl. He was killed by a charging bull. To which path will he go like this?
The Buddha said:
This great elder, I spoke the sutra for him, and he all received it in his mind and practiced it, and immediately attained the third path - stream-enterer, once-returner, and non-returner;
He then abandoned the five hindrances - first, lust, second, anger, third, sleepiness, fourth, playfulness, and fifth, regretful and incorrect thoughts.
Now he was born in the non-returner stage of the sixteenth heaven, and immediately attained arhatship and transcended the world in the heavens.
